title: Buoyant force blocks with different density

content.question: Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and density <math alttext="rho sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has the same mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> as Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> but a different density, <math alttext="rho sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, than Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. When the blocks are placed in water each block floats, but <math alttext="80%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>80</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>’s volume is submerged while only <math alttext="20%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>’s volume is submerged. Which of the following correctly compares the buoyant force <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> exerted on Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> to the buoyant force <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> exerted on Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub 1 is greater than F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="F sub 1 equals F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="F sub 1 is less than F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
It cannot be determined without knowing the ratio of the densities of the blocks.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub 1 equals F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
